natural problem:
Solve
\[\frac{x(x + 1)^2}{x - 7} \le 0.\]Enter your answer using interval notation.
natural solution: Note that $(x + 1)^2 \ge 0$ for all $x.$  For the remaining part of the expression, we can build a sign chart. \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} & x < 0 & 0 < x < 7 & 7 < x \\ \hline x & - & + & + \\ x - 7 & - & - & + \\
\frac{x(x + 1)^2}{x - 7} & + & - & + \end{array} \]Also, $\frac{x(x + 1)^2}{x - 7} = 0$ at $x = 0$ and $x = -1.$  Thus, the solution is $x \in \boxed{\{-1\} \cup [0,7)}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> 7"
and h1 : "(x * ((x + 1) powr 2)) / (x - 7) \<le> 0"
shows  "x \<in> {-1} \<union> {x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x < 7}"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

\[\frac{x(x + 1)^2}{x - 7} \le 0.\]Enter your answer using interval notation. The final Answer is \{-1\} \cup [0,7)
 ### Proof
 Note that $(x + 1)^2 \ge 0$ for all $x.$  For the remaining part of the expression, we can build a sign chart. \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} & x < 0 & 0 < x < 7 & 7 < x \\ \hline x & - & + & + \\ x - 7 & - & - & + \\
 \frac{x(x + 1)^2}{x - 7} & + & - & + \end{array} \]Also, $\frac{x(x + 1)^2}{x - 7} = 0$ at $x = 0$ and $x = -1.$  Thus, the solution is $x \in \boxed{\{-1\} \cup [0,7)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> 7"
and h1 : "(x * ((x + 1) powr 2)) / (x - 7) \<le> 0"
shows  "x \<in> {-1} \<union> {x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x < 7}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For what values of $x$ is $\frac{x * ((x + 1)^2)}{(x - 7)}$ less than or equal to zero, given that $x$ is not equal to $7$? The solution set is $x = -1$ or $0 \leq x < 7$.
